definition[0]: a larger amount of something than is allowed or needed
example[0]: After you apply the oil, wait 20 minutes before wiping off any excess.
example[1]: It was an excess of enthusiasm that caused the problem.
definition[1]: behaviour which is not acceptable because it is too extreme
example[2]: a long sermon against the dangers of excess
example[3]: He lived through some of the worst excesses of apartheid in South Africa.
example[4]: The Press Complaints Commission criticized the wilder excesses of tabloid journalism.
example[5]: A strong press can help to curb the excesses of government.
example[6]: The excesses committed by a small number of soldiers have ruined the regiment's good name.
example[7]: Government forces used the situation as an excuse to perpetrate excesses against suspected rebels.
definition[2]: additional and not needed because there is already enough of something
example[8]: Cut any excess fat from the meat.
example[9]: He told the Federal Assembly that the devaluation would compensate for an excess in public spending during the past nine months.
example[10]: ships carrying in excess of 20,000 tonnes of cargo
definition[4]: a condition in an insurance policy that states that the insured person will pay a particular amount towards any damage and the insurance company will pay the rest. This condition makes people less likely to claim for small amounts
example[11]: The insurance company will pay the insured value less the policy excess.
definition[5]: additional and not wanted or needed because there is already enough of something
example[12]: An excess supply of goods and services on the market will exert downward pressure on prices.
definition[6]: bags or cases that weigh more than the limit the airline allows you to take on a plane
example[13]: As I checked in at Baghdad airport, I found that I had 100kg of excess baggage.
